conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the path of light. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object.
When the light source is directly above the object, the shadow is directly below the object and is smaller in size compared to when the light source is at an angle.
Currently, the light source is positioned such that it creates elongated shadows (A, B, C, and D) behind the objects.
